content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												If you like Final Fantasy and silly humour this game is pure win.EDIT:  After finishing the whole game on normal, I'm still very impressed and have penciled in a second playthrough on hard difficulty at some point.  Here's a more in depth analysis.First up, I love the inventory.  You can hold every item in the game but there is no problems with clutter.  You never have to worry about a full inventory or wonder if you should sell an item you may need later on.  Huge time saver, I hate managing inventory.Abilities are chosen with experience points.  There are skills and specials.  Skills are character specific, like the fighter gets sword skills, the ranger gets bow skills.  Specials can potentially be learned by 2-4 characters but only one of them can actually learn it.  For example the skill "power metal" can be learned by either of the guys but not both of the guys.  Limit breaks (yes there are limit breaks) fall into one of these two categories as well.  So there's some careful balancing to make sure your party functions well.Equipment is easy to manage and you will be needing to switch weapons/armor/trinkets from time to time to deal with various types of enemies.  Your mage wont be needing that fire damage staff against fire elementals, for example.  Equipment can be changed during combat at the cost of a turn in case you get caught by something unexpected.  Certain fights you'll be changing gear more then once as different enemies appear.Equipment can all be upgraded through crafting.  Not the sort of annoying crafting where you have to sort through tons of crap and figure out just how much rough stone you need to make enough widgets to make 20 springs.  Basically you open the upgrade menu, things that can be upgraded with your current mats are highlighted, things that can't are not.  It cuts the crap and simply boils it down to the desicion of, is this where you'd like to spend these materials?  Most of the items I was using were maxed by the end of the game with no particular effort to farm or buy materials.  2-3 weapons per char, 1-2 armors, 1-2 helmets, and a whole whack of trinkets.  The real meat of the combat boils down to resistances and damage types.  8 types of elemental damage and 8 debuffs, all with their own counterpart resist stat.  Fortunatley you don't have to memorize 16 stats for every enemy type.  When an enemy typs is scanned with your scanbot, you can hover over them to check their stats at any time for the rest of the game.There are also summons, as you'd expect from a final fantasy game, however they are not spammable in this.  You get summoning points for each kill depending on monster strength and use the summoning points to ... summon.One thing that always bothered me about Final fantasy and Chrono Trigger was how end game tended to revolve around spamming your biggest AoE, a lot.  It looked like this game was heading that direction in the mid game, but toward the end that was just not possible.  Mixed immunities ensures you aren't just spamming a single AoE forever.  This game really took all the good out of final fantasy and boiled away a lot of the crap.  8.5/10

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												by reading that title you're probably gonna assume it's a Final Fantasy knockoff, but don't be so quick to drop this game!Gameplay: you explore around the game's map in a zelda/dragon quest style overworld map,you can use arrow keys/WSAD to move on the maps, but in combat it's mouse only (no gamepad support)the game is a turn based RPG, battles aren't random, but instead you run into an enemy to engage them in battle, combat is done with 4 party members, 3 of which are active in battle and one is the backup that you can switch in without wasting a turn, and also recovers their HP/MP while in backup. you got your nature based archer Anna, your cliche powerful swordsman Matt, the well-endowed mage Natalie, and the crazy gun maniac and tank summoner Lance.you defeat your enemies using all of your many equipments: weapons, clothes, accessories, Flairs which each have their own resistances/elements (there's a lot!) and they all can be upgraded to increase their effectiveness, not only that but you got skills and magic at your disposal as well!each enemy has different weaknesses/resistances that you NEED to pay attention to, unless you wanna do 0 damage, or worse, HEAL your enemies by accident, luckily you can "scan" enemies using your summoned scanbot which forever allows you to see their weaknesses/resistances.each character has their own skills to learn that are unique to each one, but there's also skills that are shared between them, but only ONE can use them so you'll have to plan around this a bit, you can forget skills if you really need to.there's also "limit breaks" not unlike a FF game you charge your limit guage by taking damage and unleash powerful moves, like a rapid-hit sword slash combo, summoning a space ion-cannon, or fully healing your partyand then you can use summons, which use SP that you gain from defeating enemies, like a dog that throws healing items to you, an Ice elemental that freezes enemies, and a cat with no legs that slashes everyone, and later on even summon boss monsters to your side!oh and there's quests that require you to grab certain (rare) items and bring them to NPCs, cause they're too lazy to do it themselves!Music/sound:this game's soundtrack is what makes it a little more unique, of course it's all original and done by an awesome artist (BTW soundtrack comes with the steam game!) it really sets the mood of the game. if you've played the flash game, the quality of both sounds and music are a LOT better on this version!Graphics:if you're looking for awesome 3D graphical eye-gasms... well you might not enjoy thisbut if you like hand-drawn 2D sprites and comical anime-style character designs this game has all of that! don't worry though the graphics are pretty well done for what they are, with idle animations for both party members and enemies alike, no static combat sprites here! and a lot of the skill/limit break animations are awesome!I should mention the entire game was originally designed in adobe flash, but personally this has to be one of the best flash graphics I've seen!again, this version has better graphics quality from the flash game. with resolutions up to 1280x800 and fullscreen! Difficulty:this game has an adjustable difficulty from 4 settings, that you can change at ANY TIME. believe me when I say it makes the difference of a cakewalk 10 hour game, to uber insane Bosses that 1-hit KO the unprepared!!the games difficulty changes the enemy stats by a percentage, making them have more/less HP and do more/less damage to youEasy (50%) normal (100%), hard (150%), Epic (200%)you get the same EXP, money and AP regardless of difficulty, some achievements require you to play on epic that's all.Replayability:other than different difficulties, the game has a "second quest" and "third quest" mode which is basically the same game again but with higher level enemies. and also has a new game+ so you can play again and again while still keeping your levels, AP, and equipment.there's a bonus area called Battle Mountain, that holds extra bosses and challenge battles, including one that puts you against  multiple bosses back to back! also you can try to finish every quest, learn every skill to max, and forge all your equipment to max, and reach lv99 if you wish to do so.Summary:even though it started as a flash browser game, it has to be one of the most AWESOME flash RPGs i've played, and in some ways better than a lot of mainstream RPGs.this steam version includes  all the "premium" features from the browser version, with better sound and graphics quality, and allows you to transfer saves from the browser game to the steam game! (read in forum how to do this)it's pretty damn entertaining, the game makes jokes on itself and the dialog, both in battle and out, can be fun to read. but, damned if your first encounter with "God Cat" won't catch you off guard, and it'll quickly remind you why this game is called EPIC battle fantasy!!THERE'S ALSO A FREE VERSION ON KONGREGATE.COM, NEWGROUNDS.COM AND ARMORGAMES.COMtry that first, this one's an UPGRADED version with all the additional content included!!for those wondering why buy the steam game over the free browser one:-second and third quests included (premium only on browser game)-higher graphics, and sound quality (1280x800, and fullscreen)-Battle Mountain area which holds the "premium" items from the browser game.-cloud saves through steam, if you realize how easily you can lose your browser game data, this is IMPORTANT!!-26 track soundtrack included with the game!!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
												This game is a must buy for anyone that is a fan of RPGs and one of the best RPGs available for the PC. The art style is very easy to look at and is one of those styles that will never look old. The animation effects during battles are all awesome to look at. The sounds make every hit and effect seem very powerful. It's not something easy to explain, until you experience it for yourself. As the title of this game says, the main focus is on the epic battles throughout the game. Lots of care and attention to detail has been put into the battle system. Gone are the random encounters from outdated RPGs. You see every enemy on the screen now and can choose whether to fight it or not. As soon as you touch an enemy, the battle instantly loads. No more waiting around for loading times. The combat system has so much depth. There are *a lot* of different strategies you can use to fight enemies in this game. Different equipment, elemental effects/resistances, skills, crafting and items are all very important in taking down enemies. The boss battles are very epic and will challenge you to see if you have been learning how to play efficiently. You will spend a lot of time figuring out what equipment and skills to use for taking down a boss.Postgame has the optional Battle Mountain area. Always thought it would be a great idea if RPGs would include a way to fight every enemy in the game during some marathon battles? Welcome to Battle Mountain. Where all normal encounters, minibosses and bosses are thrown into some very difficult battles to test just how good at this game you truely are. Not to mention the extremely difficult new enemies created for that section of the game.Love collecting achievements in games? This game has over 100 Medals/Achievements waiting to be unlocked. The music is some of the best I have ever heard in a game. You will definately find at least a few songs that you think are amazing. It fits every area and encounter so perfectly. There is also a New Game + mode where you can carry over all your equipment and skills. Enemies will level up and everything will be even more difficult this time around.There are so many things this game did right for an RPG. You are truely missing out on a great RPG, if you don't give this a try.You will spend around 50 hours trying to complete it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is by far the best parody games I have ever played.  It pokes fun at a lot of classic console RPGs, but the real heat of the game is the way they combined what made so many other games so memorable.The game is a simplistic true turn based RPG on the outside, but stesses a depth of strategy with a wide variety of equipment and monsters that have elemental strengths and weaknesses.  There isn't a single weapon or piece of armor in the game that is optimal for each and every battle (there are some that come close to defying this though).  You strenthen your weapons and armor through a basic crafting system that requires a hunt of scarce materials, but offers an item shop near the end of the game where you can buy the materials you might need at a hefty cash price.  There is even a achievement for poking...  Uh...  Nevermind.  The storyline and plot is pretty flimsy, but on the flip side, there isn't a need to grind to complete the game.I strongly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys console RPGs of the 90s, even if they didn't grow up in the 90s.  There isn't any need to play the earlier iterations of the games to keep up with the jokes.

Posted: November 25, 2016
												This game is very much a product of its time. It condenses all that was irreverent, wonderful, and magical about the internet culture of 2010. EBF4 is impressive in its scope. Its art-design remains fresh & unmistakably original. And, its level of challenge is almost without peer. It's also brimming with memes...ancient memes. References that were stale at its launch, and by now practically paleolithic. However, if you experienced the golden age of ♥♥♥♥♥ first hand, or ever doodled on drawball.com, or spent endless hours playing every free to play game that used to pop up on Newgrounds front page, than Epic Battle Fantasy 4 will be a perfect time capsule for an internet culture long gone, but warmly remembered. Highly, HIGHLY recommended for most every netizen in their mid-late 20s. For others...less so.

content:
Posted: May 6, 2016
												So, you're wondering if this game is worth your time? YES.Worth your money? Yes. definately!In this game, you control Anna, a ranger whom ends up tracking down the team of Epic Battle fantasy 3 on the accusation of them having stolen the gem of her village. You end up going on an epic adventure with them, going through adorable settings all over. The game is beautful with hand drawn settings that have tons of love in them, making every single area feel likable, even if it's not your favorite!You'll be playing with a total of 4 characters, having 1 of them on backup in case your main team falls, and for me that meant that the person on back-up often ended up being forgotten in regards to stat boosting items and equipment upgrades, but that's how i like to play the game. The person in back-up gets XP just like everyone else in battle, as long as they are alive at the end of the battle. Switching someone out with the back-up is smooth and seamless at the single press of the button, and if you regret it you can always switch right back. The battles move at your own pace, as the enemies cannot take their turn until you are done with yours, making the game move however you want it, wether you wanna go fast and spam your strongest move or if you carefully want to plan out the next upcoming turns.The game thrives on it's exploration, the humor and hidden references (which unfortunately had to be partially censored at least by name in order to avoid legal issues as far as i'm aware), but most importantly the music. Oh man, the music is great! It's often high tempo, but it calms down when it needs to, and it does a fantastic job att setting the mood for the current situation, which is really the only thing you'd truly want out of music for an RPG game.The game also features a bit of puzzle solving and NPC quests (most of which are fetching quests where you give them crafting items of different kinds) but if that's not your slice of cake, it's not a problem because the quests are entirely optional as far as i know, and the puzzle solving, while mandatory in some parts, is never so difficult that you feel like you want to take a break because the puzzle is just difficult.Now, there is a free to play version available on the web, both on Matt's own website aswell as several different gaming websites, but there are a couple of differences. Mainly, on the premium versions on the gaming websites as well as the steam edition, you can access an area called Battle mountain, which features tons of bonus equipment, items, skills, summons and more. But most importantly, it features some very heavy challenges, ones that will have even the best of players on the edge of their seats as they lose over and over, slowly making progress towards that sweet goal, giving you a dark souls feeling of success when you finally complete the ordeal! That takes me to the difficulty of this game!Overall, this game isn't particularily hard in many ways. The puzzles aren't extremely complex for the most part, the battles shouldn't give you that much trouble, and there's plenty of oppurtunity to heal yourself in between battles (one of which is just to stand around, as you do have natural regeneration on both MP and HP), but here's the fun part.On the options menu, you can instantly switch between the 4 different difficulties at any point on the world map, and since the battles are all actively triggered along with fleeing being 100% reliable, you can customize the experience according to how you like to play your games!If you want to play through the game having a chill time, you could just cruise through on easy.If you want to play through the game having a TOUGH time, you should play on Epic, which is when the game itself becomes so incredibly difficult at some parts that you might have to end up fleeing a battle, changing your entire equipment loadout and then trying again. However, if you feel that a battle is at any point TOO difficult for you, it's always possible to simply flee and turn the difficulty down.As for equipment, there is a ton of variation in everything from weapons to armor and accessories.Every character has their own type of weapons, and every type of weapon comes in a varied and unique form, ranging from a gun made of marble in the shape of a fist that will smite undead foes and steal health based on how much damage you do to a bow that will inflict random status ailments on each hit to a staff that is a literal incarnation of deaths' scythe, you'll find your favorite to use pretty quickly. However, even if you find the number one weapon you prefer, almost never will weapons feel obselete as enemies come in a ton of different elements and forms, and weapons almost always carry with them a special element, so ultimately, it comes down to deciding wether you want a weapon for its stats or if you want it because of the special effects it triggers. A lot of different equipment trigger special events before your turn starts, such as a random attack triggering before you get to act, or maybe a random positive buff on your character.The armor is divided into two groups, one with male armor and one with female armor, since there's 2 of each in the game. This is nice as upgrading one set of armor could potentially benefit both of the specified users, however i feel this is also a slight drawback as if one armor set is used by one character, the other one has to use a different once, which can lead to trouble sometimes if you are for example looking for specific elemental resistances and you only own 1 armor piece which protects against it, as you'd then have to choose which one would be allowed to equip it.Furthermore, accessories are shared across all your characters, and they come in the form of small badges, and while the effect more often than not isn't extremely impactful, it's nice to get small additional bonuses from time to time.Overall, this game is alot of fun, any fans of RPG games or JRPGs will most likely instantly love this game, and for people that aren't into RPG's yet but are looking for somewhere to start, this would make a great candidate!Rating for this game:Visuals: 9/10Audio: 10/10Gameplay: 8/10 (my only problem is that i wish there was some other way to control the battle menu besides the mouse :C)Final grade: 9/10If this game is on sale, do consider buying it, as it will 100% garanteed (by me) be worth it.Also, you gotta give him some credit, it's a single (not relationship wise) guy doing so much work, by both drawing everything, programming everything and man, you KNOW there's been put some blood, sweat and tears into this game! I love it!

												So,here I am,writing a review on this amazing game. I'm 9 hours off to have 100 hours in total put into this game,almost beating the game a second time and now,at Temple of Godcat. Let's do this.So let's get straight to the point,to me,and probably to the whole community the selling point was the humor and the artstyle. I also really like the voice in the trailer. content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Honestly one of the best games I've ever played. The items are great, the gameplay is easy to understand, and the character interaction is hilarious.Each weapon/attack/item has it's pluses and minuses. What may be great for one battle may be awful for another. This is nice because you actually need to pay attention to equips, not just get "the one armor set." You actually have to use your brain a little bit to play, but not so much that it's exahausting (for example, you wouldn't go into a battle with light creatures wearing only darkness armor, you'd be screwed).In terms of gameplay, you can switch between using your mouse or your keyboard, an option that other games lack. Also, in terms of battles, you have plenty of time to think and do what you need. While some may like time-constraints, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 provides for a more stress-free type gameplay. All your abilities and options are easy to navigate to, and thus far I have not run into a single glitch.The characters are great. That's something that could be said about this entire franchise, but especially this and EBF3. There is so much interaction between the characters, enemies, and the environment. Battle after battle can get boring, but the witty dialogue balances this out nicely.All-in-all, this game is perfect for those looking for a relaxed RPG experience: no time-constraints or reflex-speed battles, vibrant colors that don't strain your eyes, and lots of easter eggs from Minecraft, Pokémon, and more just in case the fantastic characters didn't already have you hooked.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 2
												Epic Battle Fantasy 4 (EBF4 for short) is the fourth installment of popular jRPG-esque seriesthat originated as web browser games. The series is basically a parody of famous Japanese RPG games (mostly Final Fantasy). If you want some more preview on the older games, I suggest you read my review on previous game, EBF3 (which is also on Steam), if you haven't already.But to keep things short, I'll just give you a small preludium: the series started as free browser games that were made for fun and played to kill some free time, and even EBF4 itself can be played via your browser, but there's also an expanded, paid version (AKA the one I'm reviewing now), and it's not exactly cheap, 11,99 USD. Some professional games cost as much, and thus, the game will be judged like one.So, first, what's the premise?As a rather typical jRPG like game, you can expect the usual: explore the world, find treasures, both hidden and not, talk to stupid NPCs so they can give you their stupid quests, upgrade your skills and fight the enemies ( and there's lot of those). The game world	The creator approched the matter with a safe and proven method: the world itself is open, but it's filled with various obstacles and road blockers (such as rocks or trees, but also more absurd ones, like floating clouds) that make your road linear at first, but with time you acquire means of bypassing them, one by one. This not only allows you to progress, but also lets you find hidden treasures, enemies, and other content, so you will definitely be coming back to old places through your entire playthrough.As I've said, it's a safe method that was used in countless titles. And it's not a bad thing really. Experimenting is good if you know what you're doing, but if something just works, I see no reason not to use it.The world itself will charm you with its simple graphics (which are still a major improvement over the previous one) and varied environment, as well as subtle themes to be found, such as various references to other media and clever comments spoken by your team members.  Overall it may not be masterfully crafted, but it's full of its own unique charm. CombatCombat has always been THE core element of these games, and as such I'm very happy to say it spectacularly failed to disappoint me. Not only it's great on its own, it also improved on everything from the previous games without changing the basis even slightly.Aside from the usual stuff like attacking, healing and using your Limit Breaks, there's 12 different status effect, 10 elements and over 100 unique skills which can be used BY you, or AGAINST you. Add shiploads of unique pieces of equipment and you've got EBF4.That means a vast array of different strategies that you can use to defeat your enemies, and believe me, if you play on Epic (the hardest difficulty), you will want to spend some time thinking about them.Want to debuff your enemies to such point they can barely scratch you? Sure. Want to go full offense and counter your lack of defense by making your enemies unable to move? Guess that will work too.Naturally enemies have their strengths and weaknesses, and there's a whole lot of them (147, to give you the idea), so you will have to use everything at your disposal thorough the game.Overall it's just what a good turn-based jRPG should look like. Give the players freedom in their playstyle and let them experiment. I have absolutely no reason to complain. Story and quests Each game has its pros and cons, and I've already explored the pros.Now, the story was never the main focus of these games, but it still deserves some attention. I can't really say much without spoiling it (as the story is partially revealed thorough the game). I'll just say that if you're enjoying the game itself, then the story will keep you interested, but if the game doesn't turn out to be your type, you won't stay just for the story.The quests are just what they were in the previous game - that is, fetch quests. You are told to get some items, and you either get them from defeating monsters (or buying them from shop), or from some treasure chests, or from other quests. Simple as that. I can't say I expected more, but it certainly would be nice to see a more expanded and developed quest from time to time. Say, a bunch or chain of quests that all give you key items that together allow you to challenge some hidden boss or whatever. Finale The game is moderately long, with plenty of additional content (most notably a fully optional location featuring lots of optional bosses and extremely long and challenging enemy waves, full of unique treasure), and fun gameplay will make sure you will play more than one time.If you're an old-school fan of the jRPG genre (I'm not, personally), it's a must have.If you're new to jRPGs or RPGs in general, you should at least give this game a try. If you're not sure about spending money on it, go ahead and try the browser version (or previous games whatsoever). If you happen to enjoy them, then definitely buy it, as it's only better than all that came before.I give it a solid 9/10

												Turn-based RPG created by Matt Roszak and his first game that is not binded to a browser. Full of different equipment that have varying properties to help you deal with the enemies.You will meet insanely hard bosses with attacks that may destroy your whole party if you're not prepared.And of course your party has tons of epic skills and limit breaks (which are awesome :D) that may help you on your adventure.Game is full of secrets and epic references to popular games, music and media and it has an awesome soundtrack made by HalcyonicFalconX.Story is told with humour and it makes you laugh even in grim situations.The world is pretty large so a lot of roaming is included altough you need to access a lot of quest items to roam free. In the end, game progresses in a linear fashion trough all different zones excluding some secret places and the Battle Mountain area.Also, this game has achievements. A lot of them. And they vary from starting the game to killing insane bosses on epic difficulty.Buy the game and support the developer. It is worth it.

content:
Posted: March 20, 2014
												Surprisingly fun Final Fantasy-inspired (with a little Golden Sun and Pokemon influence) JRPG-style game. The game is pretty lighthearted and doesn't take itself too seriously. Large variety of items/gear to collect, skills to unlock and chose from, and monsters to encounter. On the higher difficulties, you have to make sure your party make-up is balanced as far as elements, as monsters all have various elements and status conditions that they are either strong or weak against. Combined with the possible synergies between gear and skills, it gives the combat system enough depth to have it not feel stale after a while.Some minor knocks include lack of widescreen support and lack of built-in controller support. Also obviously, if you dislike JRPGs, this game will not appeal to you.

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I've played EBF since the first game, and it's always been one of my favourite RPGs.The game has a nice aesthetic, a classic tried and true battle system, lots of room for strategy.The characters are likable, if a bit cliche'd. The dialogue is not the best, but it is very light hearted and not intended for the overly serious.The game it'self has a large amount of content, which will keep you occupied for hours upon hours. The story alone is 10+ hours, which is double what most "real" games have thse days. And that 10 hours is a lower esitimate, only if you are fast and don't go gear hunting etc.You may see people complain that someone is daring to charge for a game you can play for free on New-grounds, Kongregate and Armour games.A couple of points against these naysayers.Firstly, you are paying to support a developer who already has this game and 3 others out for free (and others of differing genres, like bullet hell?) Don't wanna pay? you can play it for free, so how is that even a relevent complaint.By paying for this game, you gain access to extra content, an awesome soundtrack (that I hear costs $12 by it's lonesome), which can be found in the install folder. And you support a developer who has devoted years of his life to creating such content to give to the world for free, think of it as a donation.GFX 8/10 - The overworld spriates are lacking, but have a certain charm to them. The in battle sprites are full of life and charm.Music 10/10 - halcyonicfalconx never fails to deliver. http://halcyonicfalconx.new grounds.com/Gameplay 8/10 - A good old classic turn based RPG strategy battle game. Nothing groundbreaking, but don't fix what isn't broke amiright?Replayablity 8/10 - Lot's of content, newgame+, battlemountain challenges, medals, achievments.Overall Rating 8.5/10 - Well worth playing, even if you arn't willing to buy it, go play it for free on Kongregate or New-grounds

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												The Steam trailer is kind of awful. Anyway…Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a turn-based RPG. This was not my entry into the series, I played this and its three predecessors over at Kongregate. Yes, that’s right, I played this Flash game for free on Kongregate. And beat it. Several separate times. And when it came out on Steam, I bought it, and beat again. Yeah, you can play a slightly less content version of this game for free if you want. But stay with me for a little longer as we get into this recommendation.I’m not going to deny the game is a little immature. I mean, “anime boobs” is right there on the Steam page. But I will say it’s not that horrible. The fan service isn’t really overbearing, nor is it even all that present. A comparison would be, if you watch anime that includes fan service, then this game has less. If you think most/all anime is horrible and incredibly juvenile, then you should probably pass on this game. Just putting that out there.The game is lighthearted and doesn’t take itself seriously. NoLegs the cat has no legs (all the cats have no legs, actually), Matt is a big sword fan (in both meanings), etc.  Character dialogue (no voice acting) is humorous in a cheesy, silly way.Look, I bought this because I enjoyed the series, and wanted to support the developer. I do recommend getting this game on a sale. You want a demo? You don't want to buy it? Look it up online. Play it. You’ll miss out on a little bit of extra stuff. Whatever, I can’t stop you. Steam version does come with free soundtrack download though, and the soundtrack is pretty nice.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												A very cute and quirky turn-based JRPG. If you only have a laptop that's a few years old (like I do) you may need to turn down the settings a bit as there's a bit of lag. If you have a good computer, though, max it up. So, here's what you need to know about the game before you buy:1. It's a turn-based JRPG. Think Final Fantasy up to FFX and you'll get a good idea about what you're getting into.2. There is a story, though it's usually behind a lot of humor, including a bit of meta humor. If you want a game where there is a story, but with a lighthearted tone (for the most part), this should be good.3. Depending on how you play the game can be preeetty lengthy. It depends on whether you want to grind just enough to beat the bosses or grind A LOT and look around for any treasure.4. Lots of skills to learn and equipment to find, and all of them can change your appearance. It's a good way to mix and match the characters you get in terms of the roles you want them to have in combat.12 dollars is an alright price for what you get here (though it'd probably be smart to wait for a sale). If you're really stringy about if you want this game, though, you can play the first three EBF games (as well as a slightly stripped version of this one) for free on most flash game websites.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Even if you've played the flash version and have mastered it, it's still worth it getting the game because there's plenty more to it. The game is simple. It takes on classic turn-based battles inspired by RPGs. They've pretty much nailed it. The artwork is great, the music is fantastic, the gameplay can get repetitive at times (But what can you expect from turn-based games, right?) The game is fun, and it's worth playing as the story is, surprisingly better than I've expected when I've first played this game on kong. The references and humor in this game balance out the overall seriousness that an RPG usually gets. The puzzles, not the best. Some can be too easy, and some can be just plain annoying. However, with all the new additions, the game didn't keep old. It's worth the money if you've played the game or not.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												An old-school turn based RPG with a shiny modern coat of paint, that sums up Epic Battle Fantasy 4, but also explains very little.  Helpful, aren't I?  Um, anyway.  It's actually a really good time for fans of this sort of game, with game creation software in the hands of anyone who wants it, we have a lot of SNES style RPG games to choose from.  EBF4 really rises above the herd in many ways.The graphics are pleasing and detailed, which is especially nice since the game has such a wide variety of gear.There is a good variety of elemental damage and resistance in skills and gear, so that what you  wear can really change the outcome of a battle.  Along with that is the fact that you can always flee from battle and start it over, so you never have to find yourself in the awkward situation of being slaughtered by ice monsters because you wore your fancy fire armor that day.The humor in EBF4 is self-aware and somewhat silly, without being over-the-top hey hey look at me arrow-knee pie-face lulz.  Well, not too much anyway.I heartily suggest this game to anyone who likes fantasy, or epic battles, or the numeral four.

content:
Posted: February 5
												This game is great. I first played this game when it was still in development on Kongregate, having a Kong Plus membership which allowed me to play unreleased, in beta games, one of which was EBF4. I beat it once before it's official release, twice afterwards when the official release was hosted on Kongregate, and now I am part way through my fourth playthrough here on Steam, and one thing I can say is that I still enjoy this game as much now as I did when I first booted up so long ago.Now, for some actual pros and cons.Pros:+Easy to learn battle system, allowing even new players to easily hop in and play.+Fun, humorous dialogue/situations, one of the best parts of this entire game.+An awesome soundtrack, with each theme fitting the environment it plays in very well.+Well designed environments, that do actually feel like they should.Cons:-Not really a con, but if you do not properly equip your team, you are going to have a bad time. For example, not using fire-type weapons on Mr. Murderous Plant.-Some of the puzzles can be confusing, and irritating to solve.-Monoliths.-Expanding on the above point, that one battle where you cast Syphon 5 times, and it only works once, and the damn thing keeps healing itself and using charged attacks.-Expanding even further, RNG.Maybe not exactly a complete review, but it is 3:15 AM as of the time of me writing this, so excuse me for being half asleep.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												This is easily one of the best RPG's I've ever played. It has an amazing combat system and soundtrack, along with weapons, armor, and spells that do not disappoint. There are many rewarding secrets to find, bosses to kill, and quests to complete. You can customize each character (to an extent) to have certain spells and strengths that suit your play style. The story is a little bit on the plain side, but the characters dialogue and comments in battle kept me laughing and smiling all the way to the final boss. :3

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Epic Battle Fantasy has always been one of my favorite parody series, which is itself one of my favorite genres. But unlike your average "take that, Final Fantasy!" mimicry affair, EBF stands on its own in every regard:Colorful art design, imaginative enemies, and I can't think of an adjective for the writing that quite encapsulates the unique blend of self-depriciative humor. The protagonists have a "band of idiots" shtick that in any other parody would just come off as mean, but EBF manages to convey a genuine sense of chemistry, that these idiots have been working with and through each others' eccentricities. The humor really comes alive when EBF satirizes not just the genre but also its players, with Anna playing straight man to a trio of 4th-wall-breaking powergamers.It wouldn't be a Japanese-style RPG without a story, and where the first three EBF games went for the "here is a villain go fight him" excuse to skip to the action, the fourth instalment has tried its hand at some actual worldbuilding this time, though at the cost of assuming players are familiar with the events of the third game. Returning party members Matt, Natz, and Lance are quickly discovering that the various save-the-world plots aren't as standalone and isolated as they assumed, and larger forces have been resetting their little pawns whie they were busy level grinding the Pickpocket skill.As for gameplay, EBF is quickly recognizable to anyone who has ever touched a Square Enix RPG, and at the same time found its own way to keep the turn-based combat fresh. Not content with just elemental rock-paper-scisors, EBF ensures stats buffs and status effects/ailments are incredibly critical during the late game, but thankfully the player is slowly eased into it all. There's a great deal of customization, especially if you want to eek out every precious damage point from your foes, but if you feel that you're stopping too often to fiddle with menus the game leaves open the possibility of overleveling yourself (to a point). If you know what you're doing the game will be happy to throw you enough curveballs to keep yourself from feeling overpowered but never tries to make you entirely helpless either.The only real thing to watch out for is possible slowdown. Might wanna check how your computer handles Flash, since that's what this game was originally built in, and large numbers of vector images, since that's what the original Flash engine rendered in. My other main complaint is that late-game bosses can be a bit of a slog if you aren't an absolute min-maxer, but in a way that's sort of the point.Overall, EBF4 is a happy, charming little affair from start to finish. Matt Roszak has stated that he made the series so he can see a game with everything he likes in it, and the level of love put into the product from start to finish really shows through. If you like swords, sorcery, slimes, and squishing the latter with the former, I recommend giving Epic Battle Fantasy a look; chances are there will be a lot you will like as well.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												If you like the first three Final Fantasy games, you'll like this. It is originally a Flash game, but evolved to become what I think a great classic. It's combat in particular is what I think a high point in the game, the graphics and especially those auto cast skills that appear at random to bombard your enemies will always make you smile. You can have a hat that randomly calls in a tank to blast an enemy with its cannon, or a shirt that calls another tank to rain down machine gun fire to enemies. There's even an attachment that randomly calls a cat to charge at enemies, or radio in airdrop to give a medpack to someone, or cast some random element skills like poison gas, or even an airstrike that drops random stuffs, like a nuclear bomb.Of course, many boss units have some OP skills as well, like an orbital particle cannon, or some insane defensive skill that switch profile whenever hit by a skill. It is much more variable and over the top than the early FF games, yet maintains the same light heart atmosphere. Your characters will even chatter whenever something interesting or over the top happens. What's more, nobody will disapprove of the ability to summon a blackhole that can suck everyone, good or bad, in.Light hearted RPG doesn't get much better than this. If you like this type of game, this is a must have.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												This series has long been a staple of flash gaming, and with good reason. It's a totally solid JRPG-style game. It's easy and intuitive to play, well-written, and a great way to waste five minutes or five hours. It plays equally well in short bursts as it does long sessions.About the only criticisms that can be made are that the game can be a bit anime-fanboy-crude, with emphasis on fan service with breasts and scantily-clad females, but the actual characterizations of the female characters are well-done, so if you can look past the lewdness, it's really not bad in that regard. The other thing is some battles can get a bit long and repetitive. Most of the time, combat can be over quickly if you're paying attention to your elemental damage, but then sometimes you'll be up against an enemy that has a ton of health, and while the enemy doesn't pose a huge threat to you, it takes a long time to kill. Still, a few battles turning into a bit of a slog isn't that big an issue, either.Overall, it's funny and well-written and the gameplay is just an absolute charm. There are a lot of elements between the equips and elements and consumables and upgrading of items, but none of these elements are overly complex to the point where thye become annoying. It's easy to find almost any piece of information you want, and the gane doesn't penalize you too heavily for forgetting to attend to any of the ongoing tasks.A solid installment in a solid series, heartily recommended to anyone who enjoys RPGs, anime style, humor, or casual gaming experiences. Not that the game is overly casual, but it's so easy to learn, it's a great gateway into RPGs for the casual gamer.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												The Epic Battle Fantasy series started out as just a bunch of flash game you could play on Newgrounds and Kongregate back in the day (and you still can). For the longest time, they had stayed in the top rated flash games for both of those sites, and for good reason. This series is pretty obviously inspired by them, and if you're a fan of turn based strategic combat in RPGs similar to old school Final Fantasy, you'll love this game.If you're on the fence on whether or not you want to buy this, you can simply go on Kongregate or Newgrounds right now and play the free version. Now you may be wondering, "If I can play this game for free, why should I buy the Steam version?" Well other than supporting a series made by a developer who does both the coding and the artwork, with a quality soundtrack by Phyrrna (aka HalcyonicFalconX) that comes for free upon purchasing it, the Steam version comes with additional content, including a new area with tougher challenges that yields extra equipment to help you out on your main journey, not to mention being able to keep your save files on the Steam cloud. I also recommend Epic Battle Fantasy 3, which is now on Steam, and is completely free.Now this game does have some intermittent performance issues when it comes to frame rate, but you can toggle the quality to deal with it, and other than that, I believe this is well worth the money. I usually wait for games to be on sale, but I bought this game as soon as it was available on Steam, and I don't regret it one bit.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												I've been playing this game since it came out on Armor Games and Kongregate. EBF4 is the latest entry in the Epic Battle Fantasy Franchise, an RPG series inspired by franchises like Final Fantasy and Pokémon. It has an unique and recognisable artstyle and a quirky sense of humor. There is some story to be enjoyed here, but unlike some other RPGs, you will be playing this for the gameplay. You will be surprised by the lenght and depth of this game. One thing to note though, is that this is in fact a flash game, which means the game does require a mid-grade computer despite the games' simplicity and the steam overlay/keeping multiple tabs open doesn't work as well as usual. Even so, grabbing it for either a sale or the full price is a steal in my opinion. Pros:-Quirky cast with the same tone of humor-Decent Story-Unique and colorful artstyle-Good Game Lenght-No random encounters-The ability to save anywhere outside of battle-Surprisingly deep and fun gameplay, while still being very a accessible RPG-A small party of well balanced characters-Tons of videogame and other references-Decent game config options-A good amount of saves and a autosave feature-4 difficulties to choose from, providing a good challenge for everyone-Side quests and Challenging extra content to get even more stuff and replayability-Good character progression/equipment system (you should find this out for yourself, discovering what I'm talking about    here is part of the fun!)Cons:-Only on pc (although there are ways to get around this, including the web version)-Somewhat low frame cap (although it really doesn't matter for an RPG like this. Trust me, you won't even be bothered by this unless the game lags for you.)-No Shift + Tab Steam Overlay or F12 Steam Screenshots-Responds somewhat slowly when switching tabsOther things to note:-Good pieces of music, although there isn't that much music in comparison to the size of the game, which means it might get a bit repetitive at times when you've played the game this much.-There is some puzzle solving involved, although I personally think the puzzles add to the game rather than taking away from it. These won't change according to difficulty, but you don't need to be Einstein for this stuff.-The humor can get a bit weird sometimes (boobjokes, for example), which you will either love or hate about this game.-Because of the relatively large game size, you might lose interest before finishing everything. The percentage of people who finished the main story actually isn't that high. Whether this is good or bad depends mostly on the type of gamer you are.-Completing the game 100% requires a lot of time and mastery of the game. A lot. This might be annoying to some, but does provide a good challenge.I recommend this game to anyone who is open to games with semi-serious story. You don't need to be a hardcore RPG fan to enjoy this game at all, and you get a lot of bang for your buck. It happens pretty often that the ones playing these games become dedicated fans of the series. Epic Battle Fantasy 5 is currently in development and is shaping up to become even better. Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is also available for free on Steam if you want to get a good taste of the series first. Be sure to check those out if you're interested.I can't praise this game enough for what it is. Just give it a go and see if it floats your boat.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												Epic Battle Fantasy 4 has the best turn-based combat system I have ever played. That, by itself, is enough to warrant playing it. That it contains copious secrets, varied dungeons, good music and a great sense of humor is a bonus.There's a wide variety of skills and items for every party member, including skills you can only give one person and permanent percentage stat boosts to help "customize" your team. Your equipment and skill selection have a profound impact in battle, but they're all balanced against each other. Every one is useful in different situations, so you'll still be using some stuff from the beginning of the game by the end. Status effects are powerful and varied, and vital to many fights. The "swap in the fourth party member at any time" mechanic is odd at first but actually comes off really well. And if you crank up the difficulty to Epic, the game provides a mighty challenge indeed--even by the end of the first level.As for whether you should play the free version or the paid one? Well, aside from rewarding creativity, the bonus area is everything you could hope for. You unlock it piece by piece as you progress, and it offers lots of brutal fights and unique items and skills (including rematches against alternate versions of each boss, some entirely new bosses and waves of tough enemies). But best of all, it scales to your level so you can tackle each part whenever you want to and cannot beat it by grinding.Either way, free version or paid: If you've ever had fun playing any RPG at any point in your life, you should play this game.

Even with the free version there, this game is worth more than the big, expensive games you see all so often in stores. 11 out of 10.

												Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a fun, new, and exciting RPG from Kupo Games (Matt-Likes-Swords), incorporating elements from old classics and such. It involves a turn-based combat system, and will most certainly capture you into its wonderfully fun world. Take control of Anna, Matt, Natalie, and Lance as you fight your way through the world to save the world from a "malevolent god". Enjoy wonderful music by the awesome HalcyonicFalconX, while smacking around enemies, walking around, watching the characters make snarky comments, and of course, we can't forget the cats! Think what a catastrophe it would be if we forgot the cats! Oh Noes! Maybe even the God of Cats would come down and wreck revenge! Nah, that's just a stupid old story. Right?

												Rather a silly (fun!) pastiche of JRPGs, this addictive little game has enough basic puzzles and humor to make it your go-to quick fix for a little straightforward play time. The learning curve (at least on Normal) is pretty low, with few moments of true fear for your party, but getting at least one member with Revive is not a bad idea. Just pay attention to skill and item leveling (in my case, focusing on a few general purpose spells at least so far to ensure always doing at least *some* damage). I fully expect the higher levels to be much trickier, but I'm saving those for a later playthrough.Especially if it is on sale, this is most certainly worth getting if you at all like the genre!

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												Whether you're a RPG veteran or not this game was definitly worth the buy for its price. The story alone makes fun of typical adventure RPG's (like one moment someone gives you advice and your character pretty much says "well no♥♥♥♥♥♥") The characters are memorable, there's numerous items you can customize your characters to look different so you're not staring at the same people over and over again, have seperate spells and advantages and even in the beginning of the game they give you a ton of of and the enemies you face actually take some thought to figure out (there's a scanbot in this game who pretty much can show you all the recommended spell types you need to use and etc.) The graphics are sort of flash-game looking but very easy to overlook, the music soundtrack is AWESOME. During battles or even walking around I find myself bobbing my head up and down because it's so catchy whether it's playing fantasy music or viking metal. The ONLY downsides I can really think of about this game is 1) the fps rate. When you're in battle it doesn't occur but when you're traveling the world you'll find the character looking like its equivelent of lagging. This isn't really a big issue considering the rest of the game is really well conducted and 2) some instances the game can come off as easy but you can change the difficulty at ANY time during the game if you don't feel it's giving you that competative edge, so really come to think of it my second reason isn't really that bad if you can work your way around it just changing the difficulty. It's easy to figure out and enjoyable, I played three hours worth when I first got it and it felt like 15 minutes I was having so much fun with it and I definitly recommend this game.Games in relation to this one: It's like South Park Stick of Truth mixed a little with the beauty of Plants VS. Zombies.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
												First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/epic-battle-fantasy-4-first-impressions/Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a cute turn-based RPG. The art is fantastic, especially for a game of this genre.The gameplay is simple, similar to what one would expect from a game of the genre. You've got the exploring aspect and the turn-based combat aspect, both of which are reminiscent of classic RPG flash games (Dragon Fable anyone?). It's nothing too special, but it's fun enough to not warrant a complaint from me.The game's music was fantastic. I really enjoyed it and look forward to getting a copy of the soundtrack for future listening. Oh, and the artstyle, which was also very well done. Just like any other RPG, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 comes packed with a massive (and somewhat complex) skill system. It may have taken a while to get used to it, but it's certainly one of the game's positives.Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a great game, earning my recommendation. The artstyle may turn a few people away, but the game itself is fantastic (and besides, that artstyle should be selling more than it already is, right?).

												Great turn-based RPG. Get.

Your equipment and skill selection have a profound impact in battle, but they're all balanced against each other. Every one is useful in different situations, so you'll still be using some stuff from the beginning of the game by the end. Status effects are powerful and varied, and vital to many fights. The "swap in the fourth party member at any time" mechanic is odd at first but actually comes off really well. And if you crank up the difficulty to Epic, the game provides a mighty challenge indeed--even by the end of the first level.As for whether you should play the free version or the paid one? Well, aside from rewarding creativity, the bonus area is everything you could hope for. You unlock it piece by piece as you progress, and it offers lots of brutal fights and unique items and skills (including rematches against alternate versions of each boss, some entirely new bosses and waves of tough enemies). But best of all, it scales to your level so you can tackle each part whenever you want to and cannot beat it by grinding.Either way, free version or paid: If you've ever had fun playing any RPG at any point in your life, you should play this game.

												Whether you're a RPG veteran or not this game was definitly worth the buy for its price. The story alone makes fun of typical adventure RPG's (like one moment someone gives you advice and your character pretty much says "well no♥♥♥♥♥♥") The characters are memorable, there's numerous items you can customize your characters to look different so you're not staring at the same people over and over again, have seperate spells and advantages and even in the beginning of the game they give you a ton of of and the enemies you face actually take some thought to figure out (there's a scanbot in this game who pretty much can show you all the recommended spell types you need to use and etc.) The graphics are sort of flash-game looking but very easy to overlook, the music soundtrack is AWESOME. The ONLY downsides I can really think of about this game is 1) the fps rate. When you're in battle it doesn't occur but when you're traveling the world you'll find the character looking like its equivelent of lagging. This isn't really a big issue considering the rest of the game is really well conducted and 2) some instances the game can come off as easy but you can change the difficulty at ANY time during the game if you don't feel it's giving you that competative edge, so really come to think of it my second reason isn't really that bad if you can work your way around it just changing the difficulty. It's easy to figure out and enjoyable, I played three hours worth when I first got it and it felt like 15 minutes I was having so much fun with it and I definitly recommend this game.Games in relation to this one: It's like South Park Stick of Truth mixed a little with the beauty of Plants VS. Zombies.

												First impressions: http://www.cublikefoot.com/epic-battle-fantasy-4-first-impressions/Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a cute turn-based RPG. The art is fantastic, especially for a game of this genre.The gameplay is simple, similar to what one would expect from a game of the genre. You've got the exploring aspect and the turn-based combat aspect, both of which are reminiscent of classic RPG flash games (Dragon Fable anyone?). It's nothing too special, but it's fun enough to not warrant a complaint from me.The game's music was fantastic. I really enjoyed it and look forward to getting a copy of the soundtrack for future listening. Oh, and the artstyle, which was also very well done. Just like any other RPG, Epic Battle Fantasy 4 comes packed with a massive (and somewhat complex) skill system. It may have taken a while to get used to it, but it's certainly one of the game's positives.Epic Battle Fantasy 4 is a great game, earning my recommendation. The artstyle may turn a few people away, but the game itself is fantastic (and besides, that artstyle should be selling more than it already is, right?).

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												I loved this game! Epic Battle Fantasy 4 (or ebf4) is a Strategy RPG similar to Final Fantasy 6 and below. There are Four main characters, Matt the theiving, high attack high defense tank, Natalie, the good natured mage, Lance, the phsycotic, perverted gun freak, and Anna, the tree hugging goody two shoes with a bow. the game starts off with you in the overworld, and when you enter a hostile area, you'll notice the enemy sprites. Yes, the creator got rid of random battles. Thank Christ. when you enter battle, you control three of the four hero's attacks and strategies along with equips. for strategies there is "benching" a character for another, there is switching turns for a character, surrender, and block for the most part. equips follow the rules of, you can change wepons, outfits, flair mid battle, but it costs you a turn, same with consumables. attacks are the highlights of the game. each character can learn their own special set of "skills" for them only, but you ccan find "specials" out in the feild usually after boss fights or quests. theses "specials" can be used by any character provided they meet the parameters. overall, the game is fun, some very small tech bugs, good design and a wacky story. 8.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												Epic Battle Fantasy as a series is, in my opinion, the one of (if not) the best indie RPGs that I've played in... quite possibly ever.The game is well done and there are countless different ways to build your characters early on, though this drops off a bit due to being able to get everything later (bar a few spells/abilities that are 1-person only). The combat system, while basic, works great with very little errors outside ones made by the player.The maps are also well designed and often have more secrets in them than meets the eye, in many cases either requiring a return trip or waiting for something to flash upon the screen (though block puzzles, in my eyes, are unforgivable!).The 'many ways to build a character' is even more evident because of the inclusion of the 4th character (fitting that you get the 4th member in the 4th game), meaning that someone is back in the sidelines ready for action should you need to swap one of your (three) party members out.Cleverness and hilarity is also abundant in EBF with countless (sometimes censored due to copyright) references and/or memes.As I write the review, I have not actually gotten to any of the 'Premium' (Read: Pay for) part of the game, as I'm doing an Epic difficulty playthrough and have not started the Battle Mountain or Survival battles.If you're looking to try the game, go to some place like Kongregate and play it there to see if it's to your liking.If you're looking to get the game (and support the amazing developer), buy it.Don't anger the cats by the way; they tend to bring about the apocalypse in the form of elder gods when you do so.November 2015 Edit: Still amazing, though I forgot to mention (long ago in the original review) that this takes an obscene amount of comp usage for no real reason, so don't be surprised with large amounts of slowdown!

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Easily one of the best indie games of recent years. If not one of the best Turn-based RPGs of all time. Speaking as someone who has never played a traditional turn-based RPG prior to finding this game on Kongregate years ago (Unless Mario RPG counts, which i don't think it does.) I can therefore say that this game is a PERFECT gateway RPG. Just enough depth in it's combat system to make vetrans feel welcome, while not alienating newcomers like alot of other RPGS do (Xenoblade and Final Fantasy X come to mind)The gameplay (once it gets rolling) consists of 3 party members (with 1 in backup). Anna is the support class with her basic attacks not doing all to much damage but having alot of skills to debuff enemies or inflict them with bad statuses.Matt is the physical attacker, with alot of non-elemental high power skills.Natillie is the Magic user / Healer with most of her power revolving around her ability to deal elemental damage or heal/revive part memebers.Lance is the glass canon with not much defence or HP, but with a ton of enemy devestating moves.When you complete battles, you gain EXP and money (In this case, Choclate Coins) like other RPGs. You also gain AP which can be used to level up or learn new Skills or SpecialsThe difference between Skills and Specials is that Skills are character specific, whereas Specials consist of a pool that multiple characters can learn from. Each special can only be learnt by one party member. This makes for some intresting strategic opertunities as alot of arts are here. This game also has Limit Breaks, which to be honest, are not that much different than in Final Fantasy 7. But for those of you unfamilliar, Limit Breaks are powerful attacks that can only be used once a character has taken enough damage. What's different here, however, is that limit breaks can be saved for later use as the attack command is still there, where as to do so in Final Fantasy 7, you would need to keep using Magic instead of attacking.The equipment system in this game is in my opinion the best type of equipment system in any RPG. No 2 pieces of equipment are exactly the same, nor are there any that are inherently better than other pieces. They all have their own use with their own stats and resistances. I cannot think of any other RPG where i was never like "Oh, this sword does more damage than that sword with no downsides. Better sell my old sword for this upgraded one"The music is annother shining point of this game. Phyrnna did an amazing job. Explaining it can't do it justice, so i suggest you listen to it for yourself.Overall, 10/10. If you are looking for annother good RPG that isn't too confusing to get into, look no furher than Epic Battle Fantasy 4.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7
												I bought this game from the Overwhelmingly Positive Humble Bundle for 1€.I can't believe i'm writing a review of this game on Steam after playing EBF2 on Newgrounds in 2009. Time flies.What is this game about? How the description on the store page says, this is a turn based rpg with cute graphics and stupid humor, how i like it. At first the gameplay seems simple but the game tells you from the first battle to scan every enemies because elemental weakness and resistances are the core of this game.The game gives you a lot of equipment because to succeed you need to change your gear before starting an encounter or between waves to not be overwhelmed by your opponents. This is a good layer of strategy alongside the usual buff your party and debuff your enemies.This brings another point i liked of this game, the forging. It's quite simple here, you need to have the materials acquired by slaying enemies or bought by stores to increase the atrritubutes of your gear and some also have passives like random chance to summon a belly flopping mammoth on an enemy each turn, auto cast buffs on your party or a damaging spell after attacking. So try equip and upgrade different piece of gear for some nice combos, don't focus on what looks the best!The plot is quite simple and funnily enough it serves just as a background for our "heroes" to adventure on the map and acquire gear while doing stupid stuff. That's the charm of this series, the party is a bunch of goofballs with barely working brains. As Anna said: "I have no idea how they survived this long with no survival skills". Quite a different tone from your usual RPG.Finally, the soundtrack, which is free by the way, is really good. It set up the pace perfectly with happy tunes while exploring the grass areas or fighting the early enemies, to dark tones in the toughest fights. The composer is really good and she made EBF3 music too, check that out!Now, after praising basically everything, i will nitpick a couple of complains. First of all, some fights will drag a lot, expecially on higher difficulties, where the stats of enemies are increased, and when i saw an encounter was composed of 7 waves i was already rolling my eyes after finishing another long wave or a boss fight. I don't think it's boring, but i tended to overthink my strategy and equip for each wave and probably my brain was melting.Second problem is that the game offers 4 characters, but unfortunatly it's best to focus on 3 and two slots are occupied by Matt (warrior) and Nat (Mage) for their highly specialized stats so the third slot is contested by Lance (Gunner) and Anna (Archer) that overlap a bit on their utility but many guides and myself went with Anna in the end since she is the newcomer and brings a bit more on the table than Lance (cough, evasion buff).To conclude my fanboy review, i say this game gave me more than 30 hours of enjoyment for just 1€, and i plan to play   new game+ on Epic difficulty, but i can say that i should have bought this earlier, even at full price (11€.... not a lot) because it's a bargain for someone that enjoyed in his youth Final Fantasy and other turn based rpgs in the PSX era. Just don't let the "anime" graphic, "childish" humor and flash coding influence your opinion on this game.If you aren't sure, you can play this for free on Kongregate or Newgrounds, the only thing you will miss is Battle Mountain, another end game with extra loot, but unrelated to the main quest, so you aren't missing any plot by not playing it. So you also have a demo, what more do you want?! :DNow, i'm waiting for EBF5, currently in development, and this time i will get it as soon as possible.TL. DR. game is good!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												This game I bought because the different art styles were all cute and interesting. What followed was a shockingly good experience that I really didn't see coming.This game is based on RPGs like Final Fantasy and Golden Sun, but where they can be very slow (the former, particularly), this one is incredibly fast paced. I've played a fair amount of FFxiii, but I managed to catch up to my playtime for that game in a much shorter span due to how enveloping this game can be; I've wiled away more than one night by just playing the story of this.Grinding is possible, but wholly unneeded. It seems most of the enemies have some kind of scaling, but maybe I was just at the perfect level for everything... Not being able to tell which it is is a very positive thing.It also have a Game+ mode where you just restart the story with all your levels, skills and equipment. This is a nice feature, but I wish it had asked first as I was close to a few end game achieves that reset with the story.The actual gameplay is, as I said, fast and flowing. A little less dependence on the mouse would have been nice (you need to click to exit combat, for example), but I still love the way this game controls. Although the interface is mind-bogglingly complicated when you first see it, everything has its place and all fits together surprisingly well for a system as detailed as this. There're skill trees, equipment collecting, weapon and armour modifications, 'flair' trinkets, stat boosters, element resistance, buffs/debuffs... You get the point. But by a few hours into the game, I understood the majority of it.Character balancing was a bit off for me... I dunno if it was bad use of stat items and skills, but my best fighter was also my best healer and had half the max health of my others. Due to the sheer number of options, I found it hard to keep it straight in my head which character should have which (I did consider making some kind of spreadsheet, but decided against it), but I managed to complete the game on normal difficulty without too much hassle. Don't think I ever lost a fight.Enough about gameplay, what about the story and tone? The tone is brilliant. Spot on. Phenomenal. It'd be worth playing this for the characters' interactions alone. It plays beautifully with RPG and gaming tropes, references are everywhere and as I said at the beginning, the art style is amazing. Cutscenes are done in a felt-style looping animation, battles are anime and overworld travel are chibi things. They all work surprisingly well together and give the game a very lighthearted feel that becomes all the better when the team encounter horrific atrocities.Also there's a little easter egg that I stumbled upon entirely by accident, but could NOT stop laughing at. I won't spoil it. But damn. It just epitomises the game.Overall, this is a fantastic light RPG that is deep enough in gameplay to be elevated beyond the flash game it is and become one of my favourites. Resolution options are terrible, mind, and it isn't integrated with steam very well. Still. Amazing game.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2014
												Great fun->I usually skip over all types of round-bases-battle-RPGs but I'm glad I made an exception here. EBF4 is a tongue-in-cheek RPG with hilarious characters who dress as stereotypical pirates, rangers or red mages. On the over-world map you collect hidden goodies, explore branching ways and follow the farce of a storyline. If you choose to bump into an enemy the fighting starts, no tedious random encounters after any x steps. Also heroes slowly heal after battle for convenience and most creatures respawn.The battle system isn't boring but really fun with lots of different skills, weapons, equipment, usable items. Skills are unlocked and upgraded with skill points. Levels are gained by experience. Weapons and Armor are found or bought in shops and upgraded with items. There are also summons usable by anyone, limit breaks and "specials" which are skills you can assign to complement a characters skill set like a fire attack or a heal spell.You may try out the EBF game series on some websites for free to understand how the game works.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2015
												I've had nothing but a good time playing this game.It's a JRPG style turn based combat game, with an overworld map exploration aspect to it (secrets to be found, items that open up new areas and paths usually to treasure in old areas).There are no random encounters, and only optional enemies respawn; once you clear a 'path-blocking' encounter it remains cleared.  Turn-based combat with a focus on using skills/spells that the enemies are weak to, with a party-wide 'summon meter', lots of items and equipment to be had all with varying effects to them such as "randomly summons a wooly mammoth to fall from the sky onto an enemy each round", "randomly blesses the character", "counters attacks with xxxxx skill" things like that.The humor in the character/NPC dialogs is light hearted if a bit geared towards a younger crowd (not kids though).Fans of turn based RPGs should give this one a shot, it's very easy to play in short bursts when you feel that RPG itch, or you can get 30+ hours out of it like I have so far!

Or even better, it gets crushed by a falling mammoth out of nowhere. Or two of them.If you feel that's underwhelming, maybe this isn't for you. I recommend you play the free flash games, Epic Battle Fantasy 1~4, to see how you like it before buying it. They're on Kongregate and other flash game sites.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												A game that doesn't look great but is rated 98% on Steam, uh..? Okay, let's try the Flash version... Ah, the agony, you have to point and click to move the character around, they're moving on a grid and you get ugly icons everywhere you point at... My, my. The character designs aren't exactly good... Okay, since these are both one-man projects, I'll at least say that it looks much better than Undertale. It also beats it in terms of laughs and overall complexity.Really. It's absolutely hilarious, and also excrutiatingly overwhelming at the beginning of the game. Ah, those crafting materials...!After an hour I decided to buy the Steam version, and couldn't stop playing it ever since. This is nothing like a RPG Maker game, it seems to use its very own engine (which, amusingly, is quite slow even on a high-end PC... Thankfully it's still playable). This has a lot of advantages.It pays respects to its elders but never tries to be lazy about anything. My main complaint? It's a very difficult game... If you want to 100% it, you'll suffer. A lot. Be prepared to spend tens of hours on it. I'll just be happy with at least two thirds of the achievements. If you don't mind not getting everything, then... I get it's doable. But you'll still need to grind a lot, or use a money cheat to buy all of the items you need.And this was my 42nd Steam review, a milestone for any self-respecting geek. Not my finest hour, though!

number of helpful: 37 of 72 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I know what you're thinking. "This guy hasn't even started playing this game yet, why should I listen to his review?"Well, the truth is, I played the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of this game's free version on Kongregate.  I also played the♥♥♥♥♥♥of EPF3.  And let me tell you, if there is any game on Kongregate that deserves to make it to the big time, its EPF4.Epic Battle Fantasy 4 once again stars the trio of heroic, yet dimwitted adventurers Matt, Natalie and Lance.  This time, however, they're joined by a new character, the ranger Anna, who is easily the smartest of the bunch.  Together, the four this time must travel across the land, searching for crystals and uncovering clues about a new feline menace.Epic Battle Fantasy has always prided itself on gut busting comedy and intense, over the top action, and this game is no exception.  There are hundreds of weapons, skills and summons to collect and use against literally hundreds of enemies, and the game is full of tongue in cheek moments such as Nat's oftentimes futile efforts to get Matt and Lance to care about the environment, or Anna trying to curb Matt's kleptomaniac tendencies.Also, is case you're wondering why you should buy this version, well, its because it grants you access to the Premium Pack.  This pack adds a ton of new content to the game, including new weapons, new armor, new summons, new enemies and bosses, and even an entirely new area.If you're a fan of turn based rpgs, of self-referential comedy, or just plain fun RPGs, then you owe it to yourself to try this out.  Check out the free version on Kongregate, and if you enjoy it, you should definitely considering going Premium by buying the Steam version.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												Honestly this game is really good and was worth the ten bucks. I'm 17 hours in and still haven't beat it so there's definetely quite a bit of content here. The enemies all look different, yet are distinct to their element. The art all and all is very good, with limit breaks giving you these fun crazy destructive attacks. There is a bit of grinding and the combat is turn based, so if you don't like turn based combat this game isn't for you. The grind is pretty minimal and throughout the story are the fairly generic characters making funny remarks and conversation to keep you interested, but there isn't any award winning plot here, as the game doesn't take itself seriuosly, but that gives it creative freedom for some funny moments to keep it more fun than serious.                So overall this game is 8/10 which for 10 bucks is pretty good. It probably wont last more than 20 hours for most people though because I'm basically at the end, but overall I enjoyed it and I think it's pretty good. You can try the game out in the browser if you'd like to see if you enjoy it first, but the steam version has WAY more content and is definetely worth it if you like games from KupoGames. If this game is on sale for less than 5 bucks like it is at the time of the review, I'd say definetely get it if you're into this genre.
